title: Rates of IUCD discontinuation and its associated factors among the clients of a social franchising network in Pakistan
authors: Asmat SK, Shaikh BT, Hameed W, Bilgrami M, Mustafa G, Ali M, Ishaque M, Hussain W, Ahmed A
population: Female clients  of  Suraj Centers that had received an IUCD
outcomes-bf: Knowledge about IUCD, Accessiblity and use of IUCD,
outcomes-behavior: Provider quality of care, client satisfaction, and discontinuation rates

title: Changes in the proportion of facility-based deliveries and related maternal health services among the poor in rural Jhang, Pakistan: Results from a demand-side financing intervention
journal: International Journal for Equity in Health, 2011, 10(57): 1-12
population: Pregnant women in the two poorest quintiles in Jhang district
intervention: Social marketing of voucher booklets valued at Rs.4,000 ($48), including three ANC visits, a PNC visit, an institutional delivery, and a postnatal family planning visit, were sold for Rs. 100 ($1.2) to low-income women targeted by project outreach workers.
outcomes-bf: Perceptions of institutional delivery and family planning
outcomes-behavior: Changes in ANC, institutional delivery, PNC, and family planning use
smbc: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

outcomes-bf: Cost of care; Access to  poor

Quality of Care: These were provider training in abortion, choice of methods, information given to the clients, client satisfaction,

title: Using and joining a franchised private sector provider network in Myanmar
authors: O'Connell K, Hom M, Aung T, Theuss M, Huntington D
population: Married female clients age 15-49 receiving RH care from  franchised clinics; female  sex workers receiving STI care from franchised clinics; male and female franchised clinic providers.
outcomes-bf: Client motivation (attitudes, and quality perception) to  use  and provider motivations (incentives) to join franchised clinics

title: Reaching youth through franchise clinics: Assessment of Kenyan private sector involvement in youth services

title: Involving husbands in safe motherhood: Effects of the SUAMI SIAGA campaign in Indonesia
population: Primary audience: Men of reproductive age; Secondary audience: married women  of reproductive age, community leaders and groups,  midwives
intervention: Mass media campaign, including public service announcements, television and radio broadcasts, and print material
outcomes-bf: Exposure to campaign, Changes in knowledge and information-seeking and information-sharing behaviors
outcomes-behavior: Percent of men reporting helping a women who was experiencing pregnancy complications
